name: COM LIT H1A
about:
Expository writing based on analysis of selected masterpiece
s of ancient and modern literature. Limited to 10 qualified 
freshmen and/or sophomores who meet for round-table discussi
ons and attend weekly tutorial sessions. Individual assignme
nts provide each student with the opportunity to exploit his
 or her linguistic and literary training. H1A satisfies the 
first half of the Reading and Composition requirement, and H
1B satisfies the second hal

name: COM LIT H1B
about:
Expository writing based on analysis of selected masterpiece
s of ancient and modern literature. Limited to 10 qualified 
freshmen and/or sophomores who meet for round-table discussi
ons and attend weekly tutorial sessions. Individual assignme
nts provide each student with the opportunity to exploit his
 or her linguistic and literary training. H1A satisfies the 
first half of the Reading and Composition requirement, and H
1B satisfies the second

name: COM LIT N1A
about:
Expository writing based on analysis of selected masterpiece
s of ancient and modern literature. Satisfies the first half
 of the Reading and Composition requirement.

name: COM LIT N1B
about:
Expository writing based on analysis of selected masterpiece
s of ancient and modern literature. Satisfies the second hal
f of the Reading and Composition requirement.

name: COM LIT R1A
about:
Expository writing based on analysis of selected masterpiece
s of ancient and modern literature. R1A satisfies the first 
half of the Reading and Composition requirement, and R1B sat
isfies the second half.

name: COM LIT R1B
about:
Expository writing based on analysis of selected masterpiece
s of ancient and modern literature. R1A satisfies the first 
half of the Reading and Composition requirement, and R1B sat
isfies the second half.

name: COM LIT R2A
about:
Expository writing done in connection with the reading of se
lected masterpieces of ancient and modern literature and the
 study of selected French texts read in the original. Course
 will prepare students for more advanced work in French. R2A
 satisfies the first half of the Reading and Composition req
uirement, and R2B satisfies the second half.

name: COM LIT R2B
about:
Expository writing done in connection with the reading of se
lected masterpieces of ancient and modern literature and the
 study of selected French texts read in the original. Course
 will prepare students for more advanced work in French. R2A
 satisfies the first half of the Reading and Composition req
uirement, and R2B satisfies the second half.

name: COM LIT R3A
about:
Expository writing done in connection with the reading of se
lected masterpieces of ancient and modern literature and the
 study of selected Spanish texts read in the original. Cours
e will help prepare students for more advanced work in Spani
sh. Satisfies the second half of the Reading and Composition
 Requirement.

name: COM LIT R3B
about:
Expository writing done in connection with the reading of se
lected masterpieces of ancient and modern literature and the
 study of selected Spanish texts read in the original. Cours
e will help prepare students for more advanced work in Spani
sh. Satisfies the second half of the Reading and Composition
 Requirement.

name: COM LIT 20
about:
An introductory level exploration of a specific author, work
, theme or literary movement in an international context. Em
phasis on the ways in which literature has played (and conti
nues to play) a crucial role in the relationship between dif
ferent cultures, traditions, and languages. Readings and top
ics to vary from semester to semester.

name: COM LIT 20A
about:
An introduction to problems of the comparative study of lite
rature and philosophy. Emphasis on principles of comparative
 methods and literary and philosophical analysis with focus 
on selected literary, philosophical, critical, and theoretic
al texts from antiquity to the present. Readings in English.

name: COM LIT 20B
about:
An introductory level exploration of the study of social and
 cultural issues in relation to literature. Examining some o
f the conceptual and thematic places where literature and so
cial sciences topics (race, gender, social and class structu
re, law) cross over into each others' domains, we will ask w
hat it means to read literary texts along with social scienc
es methodologies. The focus will be on reading of fiction an
d alongside methodological texts of the social sciences

name: COM LIT 20C
about:
An introductory level exploration of the study of literature
 and history. Examining the literature and historical events
 of a chosen period (ancient, medieval, renaissance and earl
y modern, modern, contemporary), we will engage in readings 
of literature, art, and critical texts in order better to un
derstand the imaginative and real worlds of other times and 
places. Readings and topics to vary from semester to semeste
r.

name: COM LIT 24
about:
The Freshman Seminar Program has been designed to provide ne
w students with the opportunity to explore an intellectual t
opic with a faculty member in a small seminar setting. Fresh
man seminars are offered in all campus departments and topic
s vary from department to department and semester to semeste
r. Enrollment limited to fifteen freshmen.

name: COM LIT 39H
about:
Freshman and sophomore seminars offer lower division student
s the opportunity to explore an intellectual topic with a fa
culty member and a group of peers in a small-seminar setting
. These seminars are offered in all campus departments; topi
cs vary from department to department and from semester to s
emester. Enrollment limits are set by the faculty, but the s
uggested limit is 25.

name: COM LIT N40
about:
A study of women as portrayed in literature, and of women wr
iters. Selected readings on a topic which varies from summer
 to summer, detailed consideration of both literary techniqu
es and the problems of women.

name: COM LIT 41A
about: Comparative study of masterpieces of world literature.

name: COM LIT 41C
about: Comparative study of masterpieces of world literature.

name: COM LIT 41D
about: Comparative study of masterpieces of world literature.

name: COM LIT 41E
about: Comparative study of masterpieces of world literature.

name: COM LIT N41A
about: Comparative study of masterpieces of world literature.

name: COM LIT N41B
about: Comparative study of masterpieces of world literature.

name: COM LIT N41C
about: Comparative study of masterpieces of world literature.

name: COM LIT N41D
about: Comparative study of masterpieces of world literature.

name: COM LIT 50
about:
A creative writing workshop for students who wish to study t
he theory and practice of writing as they work in a variety 
of forms and media.

name: COM LIT 60AC
about:
Study of the ethnic diversity of American literature. Topics
 will vary from semester to semester, but may include such t
hemes as Cultures of the City, Gender, Race, Ethnicity in U.
S. Literature, Race and Identity. Students should consult th
e department's course bulletin well before the beginning of 
the semester for details.

name: COM LIT N60AC
about:
Study of the ethnic diversity of American literature. Topics
 will vary from summer to summer but may include such themes
 as gender, race, ethnicity, marriage, sexuality, identity, 
and the supernatural. Students should check the department's
 bulletin boards for summer course listings and further deta
ils.

name: COM LIT W60AC
about:
Study of the ethnic diversity of American literature. Topics
 will vary from semester to semester, but may include such t
hemes as Cultures of the City, Gender, Race, Ethnicity in U.
S. Literature, Race and Identity. Students should consult th
e department's course bulletin well before the beginning of 
the semester for details.

name: COM LIT 98
about:
Group study in a field that may not coincide with that of an
y regular course and must be specific enough to enable stude
nts to write essays based upon their studies.

name: COM LIT 98BC
about:
Berkeley Connect is a mentoring program, offered through var
ious academic departments, that helps students build intelle
ctual community. Over the course of a semester, enrolled stu
dents participate in regular small-group discussions facilit
ated by a graduate student mentor (following a faculty-direc
ted curriculum), meet with their graduate student mentor for
 one-on-one academic advising, attend lectures and panel dis
cussions featuring department faculty

name: COM LIT 100
about:
An introduction to problems of the comparative study of lite
rature and culture. Emphasis on principles of comparative me
thods and analysis with focus on selected literary, critical
, and theoretical texts from antiquity to the present. Readi
ngs in English.

name: COM LIT 100A
about:
An introduction to problems of the comparative study of lite
ratures of the world in international and cross-cultural per
spective along with philosophical texts and approaches. Emph
asis on principles of comparative methods and analysis with 
focus on issues of philosophy and ethics along with selected
 literary, critical, and theoretical texts. Readings in Engl
ish.

name: COM LIT 100B
about:
An introduction to problems of the comparative study of lite
ratures of the world in international and cross-cultural per
spective. Emphasis on principles of comparative methods and 
analysis with focus on contemporary social and cultural issu
es in at least one foreign culture along with selected liter
ary, critical, and theoretical texts. Readings in English.

name: COM LIT 100C
about:
An introduction to problems of the comparative study of lite
rature and historical study. Emphasis on principles of compa
rative methods and analysis with focus on selected literary,
 critical, and theoretical texts from antiquity to the prese
nt. Readings in English.

name: COM LIT 100D
about:
An introduction to problems of the comparative study of lite
ratures of the world in international and cross-cultural per
spective . Emphasis on principles of comparative methods and
 analysis with focus on contemporary social and cultural iss
ues in at least one foreign culture along with selected lite
rary, critical, and theoretical texts.

name: COM LIT 112A
about:
This is a course of beginning Modern Greek involving speakin
g, reading and writing. Modern Greek pronunciation, vocabula
ry, grammar and syntax is studied. In this course there is a
lso an emphasis in practice of oral language skills.

name: COM LIT 112B
about:
Modern Greek pronunciation, vocabulary, grammar and syntax s
tudied. The forms of writing (prose, poetry, drama) are stud
ied through literary texts as auxiliary to the acquisition o
f compositional skills.

name: COM LIT 120
about:
Examination of selected aspects of the Biblical tradition an
d their relevance to the study of later literature.

name: COM LIT 151
about:
The literature of Greece, Rome, the Biblical lands, and othe
r ancient civilizations of the Mediterranean basin.

name: COM LIT 152
about: The literature of the Middle Ages.

name: COM LIT 153
about: European literature of the Renaissance.

name: COM LIT 154
about: Literature of the 18th and 19th centuries.

name: COM LIT 155
about: Literature of the 19th and 20th centuries.

name: COM LIT 156
about:
Comparative study of American, Native-American, Spanish-Amer
ican, Caribbean, and Brazilian literature and culture. Readi
ngs chosen to illustrate diverse attitudes of Americans towa
rd their culture, politics, and environment.

name: COM LIT 156AC
about:
Study of the ethnic diversity of American literature. Topics
 will vary from semester to semester, but may include such t
hemes as Cultures of the City, Gender, Race, Ethnicity in U.
S. Literature, Race and Identity. Students should consult th
e department's course bulletin well before the beginning of 
the semester for details.

name: COM LIT 165
about:
Study of the earliest myth texts and of the progressive grow
th of literature out of myth to the present day. Myth and or
al composition. Emphasis on the meanings of myth as reflecte
d in varying idioms.

name: COM LIT 170
about:
An independent studies course designed to fulfill a need int
rinsic to the undergraduate major's program which cannot oth
erwise be satisfied because it involves either a literature 
not covered in regularly scheduled course offerings or a spe
cial methodological framework or bias of selection.

name: COM LIT 171
about:
This course frames methodologically selected topics in Moder
n Greek Literature and places them in their historical, soci
al or cultural context.

name: COM LIT 190
about:
Seminar-style treatment of a major topic in Comparative Lite
rature. Substantial paper required.

name: COM LIT H195
about:
Preparation and writing of an honors thesis under the superv
ision of a member of the faculty.

name: COM LIT 198
about:
Group study in a field that may not coincide with that of an
y regular course and must be specific enough to enable stude
nts to write essays based upon their studies.

name: COM LIT 198BC
about:
Berkeley Connect is a mentoring program, offered through var
ious academic departments, that helps students build intelle
ctual community. Over the course of a semester, enrolled stu
dents participate in regular small-group discussions facilit
ated by a graduate student mentor (following a faculty-direc
ted curriculum), meet with their graduate student mentor for
 one-on-one academic advising, attend lectures and panel dis
cussions featuring department faculty

about: Enrollment restrictions apply.

 of a chosen period (ancient, medieval, renaissance and earl
y modern, modern, contemporary), we will engage in readings 
of literature, art, and critical texts in order better to un
derstand the imaginative and real worlds of other times and 
places. Readings and topics to vary from semester to semeste
r.

name: COM LIT 24
about:
The Freshman Seminar Program has been designed to provide ne
w students with the opportunity to explore an intellectual t
opic with a faculty member in a small seminar setting. Fresh
man seminars are offered in all campus departments and topic
s vary from department to department and semester to semeste
r. Enrollment limited to fifteen freshmen.

name: COM LIT 39H
about:
Freshman and sophomore seminars offer lower division student
s the opportunity to explore an intellectual topic with a fa
culty member and a group of peers in a small-seminar setting
. These seminars are offered in all campus departments; topi
cs vary from department to department and from semester to s
emester. Enrollment limits are set by the faculty, but the s
uggested limit is 25.

name: COM LIT N40
about:
A study of women as portrayed in literature, and of women wr
iters. Selected readings on a topic which varies from summer
 to summer, detailed consideration of both literary techniqu
es and the problems of women.

about: Comparative study of masterpieces of world literature.

about: Comparative study of masterpieces of world literature.

name: COM LIT 50
about:
A creative writing workshop for students who wish to study t
he theory and practice of writing as they work in a variety 
of forms and media.

name: COM LIT 60AC
about:
Study of the ethnic diversity of American literature. Topics
 will vary from semester to semester, but may include such t
hemes as Cultures of the City, Gender, Race, Ethnicity in U.
S. Literature, Race and Identity. Students should consult th
e department's course bulletin well before the beginning of 
the semester for details.

name: COM LIT N60AC
about:
Study of the ethnic diversity of American literature. Topics
 will vary from summer to summer but may include such themes
 as gender, race, ethnicity, marriage, sexuality, identity, 
and the supernatural. Students should check the department's
 bulletin boards for summer course listings and further deta
ils.

name: COM LIT W60AC
about:
Study of the ethnic diversity of American literature. Topics
 will vary from semester to semester, but may include such t
hemes as Cultures of the City, Gender, Race, Ethnicity in U.
S. Literature, Race and Identity. Students should consult th
e department's course bulletin well before the beginning of 
the semester for details.

name: COM LIT 98
about:
Group study in a field that may not coincide with that of an
y regular course and must be specific enough to enable stude
nts to write essays based upon their studies.

name: COM LIT 98BC
about:
Berkeley Connect is a mentoring program, offered through var
ious academic departments, that helps students build intelle
ctual community. Over the course of a semester, enrolled stu
dents participate in regular small-group discussions facilit
ated by a graduate student mentor (following a faculty-direc
ted curriculum), meet with their graduate student mentor for
 one-on-one academic advising, attend lectures and panel dis
cussions featuring department faculty

name: COM LIT 100
about:
An introduction to problems of the comparative study of lite
rature and culture. Emphasis on principles of comparative me
thods and analysis with focus on selected literary, critical
, and theoretical texts from antiquity to the present. Readi
ngs in English.

name: COM LIT 100A
about:
An introduction to problems of the comparative study of lite
ratures of the world in international and cross-cultural per
spective along with philosophical texts and approaches. Emph
asis on principles of comparative methods and analysis with 
focus on issues of philosophy and ethics along with selected
 literary, critical, and theoretical texts. Readings in Engl
ish.

name: COM LIT 100B
about:
An introduction to problems of the comparative study of lite
ratures of the world in international and cross-cultural per
spective. Emphasis on principles of comparative methods and 
analysis with focus on contemporary social and cultural issu
es in at least one foreign culture along with selected liter
ary, critical, and theoretical texts. Readings in English.

name: COM LIT 100C
about:
An introduction to problems of the comparative study of lite
rature and historical study. Emphasis on principles of compa
rative methods and analysis with focus on selected literary,
 critical, and theoretical texts from antiquity to the prese
nt. Readings in English.

name: COM LIT 100D
about:
An introduction to problems of the comparative study of lite
ratures of the world in international and cross-cultural per
spective . Emphasis on principles of comparative methods and
 analysis with focus on contemporary social and cultural iss
ues in at least one foreign culture along with selected lite
rary, critical, and theoretical texts.

name: COM LIT 112A
about:
This is a course of beginning Modern Greek involving speakin
g, reading and writing. Modern Greek pronunciation, vocabula
ry, grammar and syntax is studied. In this course there is a
lso an emphasis in practice of oral language skills.

name: COM LIT 112B
about:
Modern Greek pronunciation, vocabulary, grammar and syntax s
tudied. The forms of writing (prose, poetry, drama) are stud
ied through literary texts as auxiliary to the acquisition o
f compositional skills.

name: COM LIT 120
about:
Examination of selected aspects of the Biblical tradition an
d their relevance to the study of later literature.

name: COM LIT 151
about:
The literature of Greece, Rome, the Biblical lands, and othe
r ancient civilizations of the Mediterranean basin.

name: COM LIT 152
about: The literature of the Middle Ages.

name: COM LIT 153
about: European literature of the Renaissance.

name: COM LIT 154
about: Literature of the 18th and 19th centuries.

name: COM LIT 155
about: Literature of the 19th and 20th centuries.

name: COM LIT 156
about:
Comparative study of American, Native-American, Spanish-Amer
ican, Caribbean, and Brazilian literature and culture. Readi
ngs chosen to illustrate diverse attitudes of Americans towa
rd their culture, politics, and environment.

name: COM LIT 156AC
about:
Study of the ethnic diversity of American literature. Topics
 will vary from semester to semester, but may include such t
hemes as Cultures of the City, Gender, Race, Ethnicity in U.
S. Literature, Race and Identity. Students should consult th
e department's course bulletin well before the beginning of 
the semester for details.

name: COM LIT 165
about:
Study of the earliest myth texts and of the progressive grow
th of literature out of myth to the present day. Myth and or
al composition. Emphasis on the meanings of myth as reflecte
d in varying idioms.

name: COM LIT 170
about:
An independent studies course designed to fulfill a need int
rinsic to the undergraduate major's program which cannot oth
erwise be satisfied because it involves either a literature 
not covered in regularly scheduled course offerings or a spe
cial methodological framework or bias of selection.

name: COM LIT 171
about:
This course frames methodologically selected topics in Moder
n Greek Literature and places them in their historical, soci
al or cultural context.

name: COM LIT 190
about:
Seminar-style treatment of a major topic in Comparative Lite
rature. Substantial paper required.

name: COM LIT H195
about:
Preparation and writing of an honors thesis under the superv
ision of a member of the faculty.

name: COM LIT 198
about:
Group study in a field that may not coincide with that of an
y regular course and must be specific enough to enable stude
nts to write essays based upon their studies.

name: COM LIT 198BC
about:
Berkeley Connect is a mentoring program, offered through var
ious academic departments, that helps students build intelle
ctual community. Over the course of a semester, enrolled stu
dents participate in regular small-group discussions facilit
ated by a graduate student mentor (following a faculty-direc
ted curriculum), meet with their graduate student mentor for
 one-on-one academic advising, attend lectures and panel dis
cussions featuring department faculty

name: COM LIT 199
about: Enrollment restrictions apply.

name: COM LIT H1A
about:
Expository writing based on analysis of selected masterpiece
s of ancient and modern literature. Limited to 10 qualified 
freshmen and/or sophomores who meet for round-table discussi
ons and attend weekly tutorial sessions. Individual assignme
nts provide each student with the opportunity to exploit his
 or her linguistic and literary training. H1A satisfies the 
first half of the Reading and Composition requirement, and H
1B satisfies the second hal

name: COM LIT H1B
about:
Expository writing based on analysis of selected masterpiece
s of ancient and modern literature. Limited to 10 qualified 
freshmen and/or sophomores who meet for round-table discussi
ons and attend weekly tutorial sessions. Individual assignme
nts provide each student with the opportunity to exploit his
 or her linguistic and literary training. H1A satisfies the 
first half of the Reading and Composition requirement, and H
1B satisfies the second

name: COM LIT N1A
about:
Expository writing based on analysis of selected masterpiece
s of ancient and modern literature. Satisfies the first half
 of the Reading and Composition requirement.

name: COM LIT N1B
about:
Expository writing based on analysis of selected masterpiece
s of ancient and modern literature. Satisfies the second hal
f of the Reading and Composition requirement.

name: COM LIT R1A
about:
Expository writing based on analysis of selected masterpiece
s of ancient and modern literature. R1A satisfies the first 
half of the Reading and Composition requirement, and R1B sat
isfies the second half.

name: COM LIT R1B
about:
Expository writing based on analysis of selected masterpiece
s of ancient and modern literature. R1A satisfies the first 
half of the Reading and Composition requirement, and R1B sat
isfies the second half.

name: COM LIT R2A
about:
Expository writing done in connection with the reading of se
lected masterpieces of ancient and modern literature and the
 study of selected French texts read in the original. Course
 will prepare students for more advanced work in French. R2A
 satisfies the first half of the Reading and Composition req
uirement, and R2B satisfies the second half.

name: COM LIT R2B
about:
Expository writing done in connection with the reading of se
lected masterpieces of ancient and modern literature and the
 study of selected French texts read in the original. Course
 will prepare students for more advanced work in French. R2A
 satisfies the first half of the Reading and Composition req
uirement, and R2B satisfies the second half.

name: COM LIT R3A
about:
Expository writing done in connection with the reading of se
lected masterpieces of ancient and modern literature and the
 study of selected Spanish texts read in the original. Cours
e will help prepare students for more advanced work in Spani
sh. Satisfies the second half of the Reading and Composition
 Requirement.

name: COM LIT R3B
about:
Expository writing done in connection with the reading of se
lected masterpieces of ancient and modern literature and the
 study of selected Spanish texts read in the original. Cours
e will help prepare students for more advanced work in Spani
sh. Satisfies the second half of the Reading and Composition
 Requirement.

name: COM LIT 20
about:
An introductory level exploration of a specific author, work
, theme or literary movement in an international context. Em
phasis on the ways in which literature has played (and conti
nues to play) a crucial role in the relationship between dif
ferent cultures, traditions, and languages. Readings and top
ics to vary from semester to semester.

name: COM LIT 20A
about:
An introduction to problems of the comparative study of lite
rature and philosophy. Emphasis on principles of comparative
 methods and literary and philosophical analysis with focus 
on selected literary, philosophical, critical, and theoretic
al texts from antiquity to the present. Readings in English.

name: COM LIT 20B
about:
An introductory level exploration of the study of social and
 cultural issues in relation to literature. Examining some o
f the conceptual and thematic places where literature and so
cial sciences topics (race, gender, social and class structu
re, law) cross over into each others' domains, we will ask w
hat it means to read literary texts along with social scienc
es methodologies. The focus will be on reading of fiction an
d alongside methodological texts of the social sciences

derstand the imaginative and real worlds of other times and 
places. Readings and topics to vary from semester to semeste
r.

asis on principles of comparative methods and analysis with 
focus on issues of philosophy and ethics along with selected
 literary, critical, and theoretical texts. Readings in Engl
ish.

name: COM LIT 100B
about:
An introduction to problems of the comparative study of lite
ratures of the world in international and cross-cultural per
spective. Emphasis on principles of comparative methods and 
analysis with focus on contemporary social and cultural issu
es in at least one foreign culture along with selected liter
ary, critical, and theoretical texts. Readings in English.

name: COM LIT 100C
about:
An introduction to problems of the comparative study of lite
rature and historical study. Emphasis on principles of compa
rative methods and analysis with focus on selected literary,
 critical, and theoretical texts from antiquity to the prese
nt. Readings in English.

name: COM LIT 100D
about:
An introduction to problems of the comparative study of lite
ratures of the world in international and cross-cultural per
spective . Emphasis on principles of comparative methods and
 analysis with focus on contemporary social and cultural iss
ues in at least one foreign culture along with selected lite
rary, critical, and theoretical texts.

name: COM LIT 112A
about:
This is a course of beginning Modern Greek involving speakin
g, reading and writing. Modern Greek pronunciation, vocabula
ry, grammar and syntax is studied. In this course there is a
lso an emphasis in practice of oral language skills.

name: COM LIT 112B
about:
Modern Greek pronunciation, vocabulary, grammar and syntax s
tudied. The forms of writing (prose, poetry, drama) are stud
ied through literary texts as auxiliary to the acquisition o
f compositional skills.

name: COM LIT 120
about:
Examination of selected aspects of the Biblical tradition an
d their relevance to the study of later literature.

name: COM LIT 151
about:
The literature of Greece, Rome, the Biblical lands, and othe
r ancient civilizations of the Mediterranean basin.

name: COM LIT 152
about: The literature of the Middle Ages.

name: COM LIT 153
about: European literature of the Renaissance.

name: COM LIT 154
about: Literature of the 18th and 19th centuries.

name: COM LIT 155
about: Literature of the 19th and 20th centuries.

name: COM LIT 156
about:
Comparative study of American, Native-American, Spanish-Amer
ican, Caribbean, and Brazilian literature and culture. Readi
ngs chosen to illustrate diverse attitudes of Americans towa
rd their culture, politics, and environment.

name: COM LIT 156AC
about:
Study of the ethnic diversity of American literature. Topics
 will vary from semester to semester, but may include such t
hemes as Cultures of the City, Gender, Race, Ethnicity in U.
S. Literature, Race and Identity. Students should consult th
e department's course bulletin well before the beginning of 
the semester for details.

name: COM LIT 165
about:
Study of the earliest myth texts and of the progressive grow
th of literature out of myth to the present day. Myth and or
al composition. Emphasis on the meanings of myth as reflecte
d in varying idioms.

name: COM LIT 170
about:
An independent studies course designed to fulfill a need int
rinsic to the undergraduate major's program which cannot oth
erwise be satisfied because it involves either a literature 
not covered in regularly scheduled course offerings or a spe
cial methodological framework or bias of selection.

name: COM LIT 171
about:
This course frames methodologically selected topics in Moder
n Greek Literature and places them in their historical, soci
al or cultural context.

name: COM LIT 190
about:
Seminar-style treatment of a major topic in Comparative Lite
rature. Substantial paper required.

name: COM LIT H195
about:
Preparation and writing of an honors thesis under the superv
ision of a member of the faculty.

name: COM LIT 198
about:
Group study in a field that may not coincide with that of an
y regular course and must be specific enough to enable stude
nts to write essays based upon their studies.

name: COM LIT 198BC
about:
Berkeley Connect is a mentoring program, offered through var
ious academic departments, that helps students build intelle
ctual community. Over the course of a semester, enrolled stu
dents participate in regular small-group discussions facilit
ated by a graduate student mentor (following a faculty-direc
ted curriculum), meet with their graduate student mentor for
 one-on-one academic advising, attend lectures and panel dis
cussions featuring department faculty

name: COM LIT 199
about: Enrollment restrictions apply.
